cards.front:
The standards for prehospital emergency care and the individuals who provide it are typically regulated by the:

(See Introduction)
cards.back: state office of EMS.

cards.front:
Which type of medical direction do standing orders and protocols describe?

(See Components of the EMS System)
cards.back: Off-line

cards.front:
Which of the following criteria is required to become licensed and employed as an EMT?

(See Licensure Requirements)
cards.back: Proof of immunization against certain communicable diseases

cards.front:
The continuous quality improvement (CQI) process is designed to:

(See Components of the EMS System)
cards.back: identify areas of improvement and provide remedial training if needed.

cards.front:
If a defibrillator manufacturer claims that its device terminates ventricular fibrillation on the first shock 95% of the time, you should:

(See Components of the EMS System)
cards.back: recognize that this does not mean the device will save more lives.

cards.front:
According to the National EMS Scope of Practice Model, an EMT should be able to:

(See Levels of Training)
cards.back: assist a patient with certain prescribed medications.

cards.front:
Which of the following statements regarding the NREMT is correct?

(See Introduction)
cards.back: The NREMT provides a national standard for EMS testing.

cards.front:
EMS as we know it today had its origins in 1966 with the publication of:

(See Overview of the EMS System)
cards.back: Accidental Death and Disability: The Neglected Disease of Modern Society.

cards.front:
An EMS provider who has extensive training in various aspects of advanced life support (ALS) is called a(n):

(See Introduction)
cards.back: paramedic.

cards.front:
The determination that prompt surgical care in the hospital is more important than performing time-consuming procedures in the field on a major trauma patient is based mostly on:

(See Components of the EMS System)
cards.back: EMS research.

cards.front:
The EMT certification exam is designed to:

(See Introduction)
cards.back: ensure that EMTs are competent and have the same level of knowledge and skills.

cards.front:
Which of the following skills or interventions is included at every level of prehospital emergency training?

(See Levels of Training)
cards.back: Automated external defibrillation

cards.front:
Which of the following is an example of a primary prevention strategy?

(See Components of the EMS System)
cards.back: Community awareness programs that emphasize the dangers of drinking and driving

cards.front:
Continuing education in EMS serves to:

(See Components of the EMS System)
cards.back: maintain, update, and expand the EMTâ€™s knowledge and skills.

cards.front:
Which of the following scenarios involves the administration of ALS?

(See Introduction)
cards.back: A 48-year-old patient whose airway is secured with a supraglottic device

cards.front:
Cardiac monitoring, pharmacologic interventions, and other advanced treatment skills are functions of the:

(See Introduction)
cards.back: paramedic.

cards.front:
Which of the following errors is an example of a knowledge-based failure?

(See Components of the EMS System)
cards.back: An EMT administers the wrong drug to a patient because she did not know the pertinent information about the drug.

cards.front:
Obtaining continuing medical education is the responsibility of the:

(See Components of the EMS System)
cards.back: individual EMT.

cards.front:
An appropriate demonstration of professionalism when your patient is frightened, demanding, or unpleasant is to:

(See Roles and Responsibilities of the EMT)
cards.back: continue to be nonjudgmental, compassionate, and respectful.

cards.front:
Which of the following descriptions most accurately portrays emergency medical services (EMS)?

(See Introduction)
cards.back: A team of health care professionals who are responsible for providing emergency care and transportation to the sick and injured
